trans-unit.source: How to connect classic VNets to ARM VNets in Azure - Solution Guide
trans-unit.target: How to connect classic VNets to ARM VNets in Azure - Solution Guide

trans-unit.source: Learn how to create a VPN connection between classic VNets and new VNets
trans-unit.target: Learn how to create a VPN connection between classic VNets and new VNets

trans-unit.source: Connecting classic VNets to new VNets
trans-unit.target: Connecting classic VNets to new VNets

trans-unit.source: Azure currently has two management modes: Azure Service Manager (referred to as classic), and Azure Resource Manager (ARM).
trans-unit.target: Azure currently has two management modes: Azure Service Manager (referred to as classic), and Azure Resource Manager (ARM).

trans-unit.source: If you have been using Azure for some time, you probably have Azure VMs and instance roles running on a classic VNet.
trans-unit.target: If you have been using Azure for some time, you probably have Azure VMs and instance roles running on a classic VNet.

trans-unit.source: And your newer VMs and role instances may be running on a VNet created in ARM.
trans-unit.target: And your newer VMs and role instances may be running on a VNet created in ARM.

trans-unit.source: In such situations, you will want to ensure the new infrastructure is able to communicate with your classic resources.
trans-unit.target: In such situations, you will want to ensure the new infrastructure is able to communicate with your classic resources.

trans-unit.source: You can do so by creating a VPN connection between the two VNets.
trans-unit.target: You can do so by creating a VPN connection between the two VNets.

trans-unit.source: The figure below illustrates a sample environment with two VNets (classic and ARM), along with a secure tunnel connectivity between the VNets.
trans-unit.target: The figure below illustrates a sample environment with two VNets (classic and ARM), along with a secure tunnel connectivity between the VNets.

trans-unit.source: This document walks you through an end-to-end solution, for testing purposes.
trans-unit.target: This document walks you through an end-to-end solution, for testing purposes.

trans-unit.source: If you already have your VNets setup, and are familiar with VPN gateways and site-to-site connection in Azure, visit <link><linkText>Configure a S2S VPN between an ARM VNet and a classic VNet</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: If you already have your VNets setup, and are familiar with VPN gateways and site-to-site connection in Azure, visit <link><linkText>Configure a S2S VPN between an ARM VNet and a classic VNet</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: To test this scenario, you will:
trans-unit.target: To test this scenario, you will:

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Create a classic VNet environment</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Create a classic VNet environment</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Create a new VNet environment</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Create a new VNet environment</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Connect the two VNets</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Connect the two VNets</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: You will execute the steps above by first using classic Azure management tools, including the classic portal, network configuration files, and Azure Service Manager PowerShell cmdlets; and later move on to the new management tools, including the new Azure portal, ARM templates, and ARM PowerShell cmdlets.
trans-unit.target: You will execute the steps above by first using classic Azure management tools, including the classic portal, network configuration files, and Azure Service Manager PowerShell cmdlets; and later move on to the new management tools, including the new Azure portal, ARM templates, and ARM PowerShell cmdlets.

trans-unit.source: For VNets to be connected to one another, they cannot have a CIDR block clash.
trans-unit.target: For VNets to be connected to one another, they cannot have a CIDR block clash.

trans-unit.source: Make sure each VNet has a unique CIDR block!
trans-unit.target: Make sure each VNet has a unique CIDR block!

trans-unit.source: Create a classic VNet environment
trans-unit.target: Create a classic VNet environment

trans-unit.source: You can use an existing classic VNet to connect to a new ARM VNet.
trans-unit.target: You can use an existing classic VNet to connect to a new ARM VNet.

trans-unit.source: In this example, you will see how to create a new classic VNet, with two subnets, a gateway, and a VM for testing purposes.
trans-unit.target: In this example, you will see how to create a new classic VNet, with two subnets, a gateway, and a VM for testing purposes.

trans-unit.source: Step 1: Create a classic VNet
trans-unit.target: Step 1: Create a classic VNet

trans-unit.source: To create a new VNet that maps to figure 1 above, follow the instructions below.
trans-unit.target: To create a new VNet that maps to figure 1 above, follow the instructions below.

trans-unit.source: From a PowerShell console, add you Azure account by running the command below.
trans-unit.target: From a PowerShell console, add you Azure account by running the command below.

trans-unit.source: Follow the sign in dialog box instructions to log on with your Azure account.
trans-unit.target: Follow the sign in dialog box instructions to log on with your Azure account.

trans-unit.source: Make sure you are using Azure Service Management PowerShell cmdlets by running the command below.
trans-unit.target: Make sure you are using Azure Service Management PowerShell cmdlets by running the command below.

trans-unit.source: Download your Azure network configuration file by running command below.
trans-unit.target: Download your Azure network configuration file by running command below.

trans-unit.source: Open the file you just downloaded, and add a local network site named vnet02 that uses 10.2.0.0/16 as an address prefix, and any valid public IP address as a VPN gateway address.
trans-unit.target: Open the file you just downloaded, and add a local network site named vnet02 that uses 10.2.0.0/16 as an address prefix, and any valid public IP address as a VPN gateway address.

trans-unit.source: You can do so by adding a LocalNetworkSite element to the LocalNetworkSites element in your configuration file.
trans-unit.target: You can do so by adding a LocalNetworkSite element to the LocalNetworkSites element in your configuration file.

trans-unit.source: The file snippet below shows a sample LocalNetworksSites element.
trans-unit.target: The file snippet below shows a sample LocalNetworksSites element.

trans-unit.source: In the VirtualNetworkSites element, add a new virtual network with an address prefix of 10.1.0.0/16 and two subnets according the scenario figure above.
trans-unit.target: In the VirtualNetworkSites element, add a new virtual network with an address prefix of 10.1.0.0/16 and two subnets according the scenario figure above.

trans-unit.source: The file snippet below shows a sample VirtualNetworkSites element.
trans-unit.target: The file snippet below shows a sample VirtualNetworkSites element.

trans-unit.source: Save the file, then upload it to Azure by running the command below.
trans-unit.target: Save the file, then upload it to Azure by running the command below.

trans-unit.source: Make sure you change the file path as necessary for your environment.
trans-unit.target: Make sure you change the file path as necessary for your environment.

trans-unit.source: Step 2: Create a VM in the classic VNet
trans-unit.target: Step 2: Create a VM in the classic VNet

trans-unit.source: To create a VM in the classic VNet by using Azure Service Manager PowerShell cmdlets, follow the instructions below.
trans-unit.target: To create a VM in the classic VNet by using Azure Service Manager PowerShell cmdlets, follow the instructions below.

trans-unit.source: Retrieve a VM image from Azure.
trans-unit.target: Retrieve a VM image from Azure.

trans-unit.source: The PowerShell command below retrieves the latest Windows Server 2012 R2 image available.
trans-unit.target: The PowerShell command below retrieves the latest Windows Server 2012 R2 image available.

trans-unit.source: Create a storage account to store the virtual hard drive (VHD) for the VM by running the command below.
trans-unit.target: Create a storage account to store the virtual hard drive (VHD) for the VM by running the command below.

trans-unit.source: Create the VM by running the commands below.
trans-unit.target: Create the VM by running the commands below.

trans-unit.source: Make sure to replace the user name and password values.
trans-unit.target: Make sure to replace the user name and password values.

trans-unit.source: Connect the VM to Subnet1 by running the commands below.
trans-unit.target: Connect the VM to Subnet1 by running the commands below.

trans-unit.source: Create a new cloud service to host the VM by running the command below.
trans-unit.target: Create a new cloud service to host the VM by running the command below.

trans-unit.source: Step 3: Create a VPN gateway for the classic VNet
trans-unit.target: Step 3: Create a VPN gateway for the classic VNet

trans-unit.source: To create the VPN gateway for vnet01 by using the classic Azure portal, follow the instructions below.
trans-unit.target: To create the VPN gateway for vnet01 by using the classic Azure portal, follow the instructions below.

trans-unit.source: Open the classic Azure Portal at https://manage.windowsazure.com.
trans-unit.target: Open the classic Azure Portal at https://manage.windowsazure.com.

trans-unit.source: If necessary, specify your credentials.
trans-unit.target: If necessary, specify your credentials.

trans-unit.source: Scroll down on the list of ALL ITEMS and click NETWORKS.
trans-unit.target: Scroll down on the list of ALL ITEMS and click NETWORKS.

trans-unit.source: On the list of virtual networks, click vnet01, and then click on CONFIGURE.
trans-unit.target: On the list of virtual networks, click vnet01, and then click on CONFIGURE.

trans-unit.source: Under site-to-site connectivity, enable the Connect to the local network checkbox.
trans-unit.target: Under site-to-site connectivity, enable the Connect to the local network checkbox.

trans-unit.source: On the LOCAL NETWORK list, select vnet02, then click SAVE, and then click YES.
trans-unit.target: On the LOCAL NETWORK list, select vnet02, then click SAVE, and then click YES.

trans-unit.source: Click DASHBOARD and notice the message stating a gateway was not yet created, as shown in figure 2 below.
trans-unit.target: Click DASHBOARD and notice the message stating a gateway was not yet created, as shown in figure 2 below.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>VNet dashboard</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>VNet dashboard</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click CREATE GATEWAY as shown in figure 3 below to create a VPN gateway for vnet01.
trans-unit.target: Click CREATE GATEWAY as shown in figure 3 below to create a VPN gateway for vnet01.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>VNet dashboard</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>VNet dashboard</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the list of gateway types, click DYNAMIC, and then click YES.
trans-unit.target: In the list of gateway types, click DYNAMIC, and then click YES.

trans-unit.source: Notice that the dashboard image changes, showing the gateway in yellow, while it is being created.
trans-unit.target: Notice that the dashboard image changes, showing the gateway in yellow, while it is being created.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>VNet dashboard</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>VNet dashboard</linkText>

trans-unit.source: This operation may take several minutes.
trans-unit.target: This operation may take several minutes.

trans-unit.source: Write down the public IP address for the gateway, as seen below, once it is created.
trans-unit.target: Write down the public IP address for the gateway, as seen below, once it is created.

trans-unit.source: You will need this address to create a local network for the ARM VNet later.
trans-unit.target: You will need this address to create a local network for the ARM VNet later.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>VNet dashboard</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>VNet dashboard</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Create a new VNet environment
trans-unit.target: Create a new VNet environment

trans-unit.source: Now that the classic VNet is up and running with a VM and a gateway, it is time to create the ARM VNet.
trans-unit.target: Now that the classic VNet is up and running with a VM and a gateway, it is time to create the ARM VNet.

trans-unit.source: Step 1: Create a new VNet in ARM
trans-unit.target: Step 1: Create a new VNet in ARM

trans-unit.source: To create the ARM VNet, with two subnets, and a local network for the classic VNet by using an ARM template, follow the instructions below.
trans-unit.target: To create the ARM VNet, with two subnets, and a local network for the classic VNet by using an ARM template, follow the instructions below.

trans-unit.source: Download the azuredeploy.json and azuredeploy-parameters.json files from <link><linkText>git hub</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Download the azuredeploy.json and azuredeploy-parameters.json files from <link><linkText>git hub</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Open the azuredeploy.json file in Visual Studio, and notice that the template creates four resources:
trans-unit.target: Open the azuredeploy.json file in Visual Studio, and notice that the template creates four resources:

trans-unit.source: Local gateway: this resource represents the gateway created for the VNet you want to connect to.
trans-unit.target: Local gateway: this resource represents the gateway created for the VNet you want to connect to.

trans-unit.source: In this scenario, the gateway for vnet01.
trans-unit.target: In this scenario, the gateway for vnet01.

trans-unit.source: Virtual network: this resource represents an ARM VNet to be created.
trans-unit.target: Virtual network: this resource represents an ARM VNet to be created.

trans-unit.source: In this scenario, vnet02.
trans-unit.target: In this scenario, vnet02.

trans-unit.source: Gateway public IP: this resource represents the public IP address for the gateway to be created for the ARM VNet.
trans-unit.target: Gateway public IP: this resource represents the public IP address for the gateway to be created for the ARM VNet.

trans-unit.source: Gateway: this resource represents the gateway to be created for the ARM VNet (vnet02).
trans-unit.target: Gateway: this resource represents the gateway to be created for the ARM VNet (vnet02).

trans-unit.source: Notice the parameters used in this file.
trans-unit.target: Notice the parameters used in this file.

trans-unit.source: Most of them have a default value.
trans-unit.target: Most of them have a default value.

trans-unit.source: You can change these values according to your needs.
trans-unit.target: You can change these values according to your needs.

trans-unit.source: Open the azuredeploy-parameters.json file in Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: Open the azuredeploy-parameters.json file in Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: This file contains values to be used for the parameters in the template file.
trans-unit.target: This file contains values to be used for the parameters in the template file.

trans-unit.source: Edit the following values, if necessary.
trans-unit.target: Edit the following values, if necessary.

trans-unit.source: subscriptionId: edit and paste your subscription id.
trans-unit.target: subscriptionId: edit and paste your subscription id.

trans-unit.source: If you do not know your subscription id, run the Get-AzureSubscription PowerShell cmdlet to retrieve your id.
trans-unit.target: If you do not know your subscription id, run the Get-AzureSubscription PowerShell cmdlet to retrieve your id.

trans-unit.source: location: specify the Azure location where the VNet will be created.
trans-unit.target: location: specify the Azure location where the VNet will be created.

trans-unit.source: In this scenario, it will be Central US.
trans-unit.target: In this scenario, it will be Central US.

trans-unit.source: virtualNetworkName: this is the name of the ARM VNet to be created.
trans-unit.target: virtualNetworkName: this is the name of the ARM VNet to be created.

trans-unit.source: In this scenario, vnet02.
trans-unit.target: In this scenario, vnet02.

trans-unit.source: localGatewayName: this is the local network you want to connect to, from your new ARM VNet.
trans-unit.target: localGatewayName: this is the local network you want to connect to, from your new ARM VNet.

trans-unit.source: In this scenario, vnet01.
trans-unit.target: In this scenario, vnet01.

trans-unit.source: localGatewayIpAddress: this is the public IP address for the gateway created for the network you want to connect to.
trans-unit.target: localGatewayIpAddress: this is the public IP address for the gateway created for the network you want to connect to.

trans-unit.source: In this scenario, this is the IP address you wrote down in step 9 above, when creating the VPN gateway for vnet01.
trans-unit.target: In this scenario, this is the IP address you wrote down in step 9 above, when creating the VPN gateway for vnet01.

trans-unit.source: localGatewayAddressPrefix: this is the CIDR block for the local network your VNet will connect to.
trans-unit.target: localGatewayAddressPrefix: this is the CIDR block for the local network your VNet will connect to.

trans-unit.source: In this scenario, the VNet you will connect to is vnet01, and its CIDR block is 10.1.0.0/16.
trans-unit.target: In this scenario, the VNet you will connect to is vnet01, and its CIDR block is 10.1.0.0/16.

trans-unit.source: gatewayPublicIPName: this is the name of the IP object to be created for the public IP of the gateway that will be created for the ARM VNet.
trans-unit.target: gatewayPublicIPName: this is the name of the IP object to be created for the public IP of the gateway that will be created for the ARM VNet.

trans-unit.source: gatewayName: this is the name of the gateway object that will be created for the ARM VNet.
trans-unit.target: gatewayName: this is the name of the gateway object that will be created for the ARM VNet.

trans-unit.source: addressPrefix: this is the CIDR block for the ARM VNet.
trans-unit.target: addressPrefix: this is the CIDR block for the ARM VNet.

trans-unit.source: In this scenario, 10.2.0.0/16.
trans-unit.target: In this scenario, 10.2.0.0/16.

trans-unit.source: subnet1Prefix: this is the CIDR block for a subnet in the ARM VNet.
trans-unit.target: subnet1Prefix: this is the CIDR block for a subnet in the ARM VNet.

trans-unit.source: In this scenario, 10.2.0.0/24.
trans-unit.target: In this scenario, 10.2.0.0/24.

trans-unit.source: gatewaySubnetPrefix: this is the CIDR block for the gateway subnet in the ARM VNet.
trans-unit.target: gatewaySubnetPrefix: this is the CIDR block for the gateway subnet in the ARM VNet.

trans-unit.source: In this scenario, 10.2.200.0/29.
trans-unit.target: In this scenario, 10.2.200.0/29.

trans-unit.source: connectionName: this is the name of the connection object to be created.
trans-unit.target: connectionName: this is the name of the connection object to be created.

trans-unit.source: sharedKey: this is the IPSec shared key for the connection.
trans-unit.target: sharedKey: this is the IPSec shared key for the connection.

trans-unit.source: In this scenario, abc123.
trans-unit.target: In this scenario, abc123.

trans-unit.source: To create the ARM VNet, and its related objects, in a new resource group named RG1, run the following PowerShell command.
trans-unit.target: To create the ARM VNet, and its related objects, in a new resource group named RG1, run the following PowerShell command.

trans-unit.source: Make sure you change the path for the template file and the parameters file.
trans-unit.target: Make sure you change the path for the template file and the parameters file.

trans-unit.source: This operation may take several minutes.
trans-unit.target: This operation may take several minutes.

trans-unit.source: From your browser, navigate to https://portal.azure.com/ and enter your credentials, if necessary.
trans-unit.target: From your browser, navigate to https://portal.azure.com/ and enter your credentials, if necessary.

trans-unit.source: Click on the RG1 resource group tile in the Azure portal, as shown below.
trans-unit.target: Click on the RG1 resource group tile in the Azure portal, as shown below.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>VNet dashboard</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>VNet dashboard</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Notice the resources added to the group by using the ARM template.
trans-unit.target: Notice the resources added to the group by using the ARM template.

trans-unit.source: Step 2: Create a new VM in ARM
trans-unit.target: Step 2: Create a new VM in ARM

trans-unit.source: To create a VM in the new VNet, from the Azure portal, follow the instructions below.
trans-unit.target: To create a VM in the new VNet, from the Azure portal, follow the instructions below.

trans-unit.source: From the portal, click the NEW button, then click Compute, and then click Windows Server 2012 R2 Datacenter.
trans-unit.target: From the portal, click the NEW button, then click Compute, and then click Windows Server 2012 R2 Datacenter.

trans-unit.source: At the bottom of the right pane, in the Select a compute stack, select Use the Resource Manager stack to create the VM in ARM, as seen below, then click Create.
trans-unit.target: At the bottom of the right pane, in the Select a compute stack, select Use the Resource Manager stack to create the VM in ARM, as seen below, then click Create.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>VNet dashboard</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>VNet dashboard</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the Basics blade, enter the VM name, user name, password, subscription, resource group, and location for the VM, and then click OK.
trans-unit.target: In the Basics blade, enter the VM name, user name, password, subscription, resource group, and location for the VM, and then click OK.

trans-unit.source: The figure below shows the settings for this scenario.
trans-unit.target: The figure below shows the settings for this scenario.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>VNet dashboard</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>VNet dashboard</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the Choose a size blade, select a size, and then click Select.
trans-unit.target: In the Choose a size blade, select a size, and then click Select.

trans-unit.source: For this scenario, select D2.
trans-unit.target: For this scenario, select D2.

trans-unit.source: In the Settings blade, click Virtual network, and then click vnet02.
trans-unit.target: In the Settings blade, click Virtual network, and then click vnet02.

trans-unit.source: Click Subnet, then click Subnet1, and then click OK.
trans-unit.target: Click Subnet, then click Subnet1, and then click OK.

trans-unit.source: The Summary blade should look similar to the figure below.
trans-unit.target: The Summary blade should look similar to the figure below.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>VNet dashboard</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>VNet dashboard</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click OK, and then click Create to create the VM.
trans-unit.target: Click OK, and then click Create to create the VM.

trans-unit.source: You will see a new tile in the portal, showing the VM being provisioned, as seen below.
trans-unit.target: You will see a new tile in the portal, showing the VM being provisioned, as seen below.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>VNet dashboard</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>VNet dashboard</linkText>

trans-unit.source: This operation may take several minutes.
trans-unit.target: This operation may take several minutes.

trans-unit.source: You can move on to the next part of this document.
trans-unit.target: You can move on to the next part of this document.

trans-unit.source: Connect the two VNets
trans-unit.target: Connect the two VNets

trans-unit.source: Now that you have two VNets with VMs connected to them, it's time to connect the VNets through the gateways previously established, and test the connection.
trans-unit.target: Now that you have two VNets with VMs connected to them, it's time to connect the VNets through the gateways previously established, and test the connection.

trans-unit.source: Step 1: Configure the gateway for the classic VNet
trans-unit.target: Step 1: Configure the gateway for the classic VNet

trans-unit.source: You need to configure the classic VNet to use the IP address of the gateway created for the ARM VNet (vnet02), then establish a connection from each VNet.
trans-unit.target: You need to configure the classic VNet to use the IP address of the gateway created for the ARM VNet (vnet02), then establish a connection from each VNet.

trans-unit.source: To do so, follow the instructions below.
trans-unit.target: To do so, follow the instructions below.

trans-unit.source: To retrieve the IP address used for the gateway in the ARM VNet, run the command below, and notice the output.
trans-unit.target: To retrieve the IP address used for the gateway in the ARM VNet, run the command below, and notice the output.

trans-unit.source: Write down the address, you will need it to modify the local network settings for the classic VNet later.
trans-unit.target: Write down the address, you will need it to modify the local network settings for the classic VNet later.

trans-unit.source: Make sure you are using the Azure Service Management API for your PowerShell commands by running the command below.
trans-unit.target: Make sure you are using the Azure Service Management API for your PowerShell commands by running the command below.

trans-unit.source: Download your Azure network configuration file by running the command below.
trans-unit.target: Download your Azure network configuration file by running the command below.

trans-unit.source: Open the file you just downloaded, and edit the LocalNetworkSite element for vnet02 to add the IP address of the gateway for the new VNet obtained in step 1 above.
trans-unit.target: Open the file you just downloaded, and edit the LocalNetworkSite element for vnet02 to add the IP address of the gateway for the new VNet obtained in step 1 above.

trans-unit.source: The element should look similar to the sample below.
trans-unit.target: The element should look similar to the sample below.

trans-unit.source: Save the file, then run the command below to configure the classic vnet.
trans-unit.target: Save the file, then run the command below to configure the classic vnet.

trans-unit.source: Make sure you change the path to point the file you save in step 4 above.
trans-unit.target: Make sure you change the path to point the file you save in step 4 above.

trans-unit.source: Set the IPSec shared key for the classic VNet gateway by running the command below.
trans-unit.target: Set the IPSec shared key for the classic VNet gateway by running the command below.

trans-unit.source: You should see an output similar to the one posted below.
trans-unit.target: You should see an output similar to the one posted below.

trans-unit.source: Make sure you change the VNet names, if you are using your own pre-existing VNets.
trans-unit.target: Make sure you change the VNet names, if you are using your own pre-existing VNets.

trans-unit.source: Step 2: Configure the gateway for the ARM VNet
trans-unit.target: Step 2: Configure the gateway for the ARM VNet

trans-unit.source: Now that you have the classic VNet gateway configured, it's time to establish the connection.
trans-unit.target: Now that you have the classic VNet gateway configured, it's time to establish the connection.

trans-unit.source: To do so, follow the instructions below.
trans-unit.target: To do so, follow the instructions below.

trans-unit.source: From a PowerShell console, run the command below to switch to ARM mode.
trans-unit.target: From a PowerShell console, run the command below to switch to ARM mode.

trans-unit.source: Create the connection between the gateways, by running the following commands.
trans-unit.target: Create the connection between the gateways, by running the following commands.

trans-unit.source: Open the Azure Portal at https://manage.windowsazure.com and, if necessary, enter your credentials.
trans-unit.target: Open the Azure Portal at https://manage.windowsazure.com and, if necessary, enter your credentials.

trans-unit.source: Under ALL ITEMS, scroll down and click NETWORKS, then click vnet01, and then click DASHBOARD.
trans-unit.target: Under ALL ITEMS, scroll down and click NETWORKS, then click vnet01, and then click DASHBOARD.

trans-unit.source: Notice the connection between vnet01 and vnet02 is now established, as seen below.
trans-unit.target: Notice the connection between vnet01 and vnet02 is now established, as seen below.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>VNet dashboard</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>VNet dashboard</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Although you can manage the classic VNet and its connection from the classic portal, it's recommended to use the new Azure portal.
trans-unit.target: Although you can manage the classic VNet and its connection from the classic portal, it's recommended to use the new Azure portal.

trans-unit.source: To open the new portal, navigate to https://portal.azure.com.
trans-unit.target: To open the new portal, navigate to https://portal.azure.com.

trans-unit.source: In the new portal, click BROWSE ALL, then click Virtual networks (classic), and then click vnet01.
trans-unit.target: In the new portal, click BROWSE ALL, then click Virtual networks (classic), and then click vnet01.

trans-unit.source: Notice the VPN connections pane shown below.
trans-unit.target: Notice the VPN connections pane shown below.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>VNet dashboard</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>VNet dashboard</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Step 3: Test the connectivity
trans-unit.target: Step 3: Test the connectivity

trans-unit.source: Now that you have the two VNets connected, it is time to test the connectivity by pinging one VM from the other.
trans-unit.target: Now that you have the two VNets connected, it is time to test the connectivity by pinging one VM from the other.

trans-unit.source: You will need to change the firewall settings in one of the VMs to allow ICMP, and then ping that VM from the other VM.
trans-unit.target: You will need to change the firewall settings in one of the VMs to allow ICMP, and then ping that VM from the other VM.

trans-unit.source: To do so, follow the instructions below.
trans-unit.target: To do so, follow the instructions below.

trans-unit.source: From the Azure portal, click BROWSE ALL, then click Virtual machines, and then click VM02.
trans-unit.target: From the Azure portal, click BROWSE ALL, then click Virtual machines, and then click VM02.

trans-unit.source: From the VM02 blade, click Connect.
trans-unit.target: From the VM02 blade, click Connect.

trans-unit.source: If needed, click Open on your browser security banner to open the RDP file.
trans-unit.target: If needed, click Open on your browser security banner to open the RDP file.

trans-unit.source: In the Remote Desktop Connection dialog box, click Connect.
trans-unit.target: In the Remote Desktop Connection dialog box, click Connect.

trans-unit.source: In the Windows Security dialog box, enter your VM user name and password.
trans-unit.target: In the Windows Security dialog box, enter your VM user name and password.

trans-unit.source: In the Remote Desktop Connection dialog box, click Yes.
trans-unit.target: In the Remote Desktop Connection dialog box, click Yes.

trans-unit.source: Once you connect to the VM, from Server Manager, click Tools, and then click Windows Firewall with Advanced Security.
trans-unit.target: Once you connect to the VM, from Server Manager, click Tools, and then click Windows Firewall with Advanced Security.

trans-unit.source: In the Windows Firewall with Advanced Security window, click Inbound Rules.
trans-unit.target: In the Windows Firewall with Advanced Security window, click Inbound Rules.

trans-unit.source: In the Inbound Rules list, right click File and Printer Sharing (Echo Request - ICMPv4-In) and then click Enable Rule.
trans-unit.target: In the Inbound Rules list, right click File and Printer Sharing (Echo Request - ICMPv4-In) and then click Enable Rule.

trans-unit.source: In the task bar, click the Windows PowerShell button, then run the following command.
trans-unit.target: In the task bar, click the Windows PowerShell button, then run the following command.

trans-unit.source: Write down the IP address for the VM.
trans-unit.target: Write down the IP address for the VM.

trans-unit.source: In this scenario, 10.2.0.101.
trans-unit.target: In this scenario, 10.2.0.101.

trans-unit.source: You will ping that address from the other VM to test connectivity between the VNets.
trans-unit.target: You will ping that address from the other VM to test connectivity between the VNets.

trans-unit.source: From the Azure portal, on the left pane, click Virtual machines (classic), then click VM01, and then click Connect.
trans-unit.target: From the Azure portal, on the left pane, click Virtual machines (classic), then click VM01, and then click Connect.

trans-unit.source: If needed, click Open on your browser security banner to open the RDP file.
trans-unit.target: If needed, click Open on your browser security banner to open the RDP file.

trans-unit.source: In the Remote Desktop Connection dialog box, click Connect.
trans-unit.target: In the Remote Desktop Connection dialog box, click Connect.

trans-unit.source: In the Windows Security dialog box, enter your VM user name and password.
trans-unit.target: In the Windows Security dialog box, enter your VM user name and password.

trans-unit.source: In the Remote Desktop Connection dialog box, click Yes.
trans-unit.target: In the Remote Desktop Connection dialog box, click Yes.

trans-unit.source: In the task bar for the remote VM, click the Windows PowerShell button, then run the following command.
trans-unit.target: In the task bar for the remote VM, click the Windows PowerShell button, then run the following command.

trans-unit.source: Next Steps
trans-unit.target: Next Steps

trans-unit.source: Learn more about <link><linkText>the Network Resource Provider (NRP) for ARM</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Learn more about <link><linkText>the Network Resource Provider (NRP) for ARM</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: View the general guidelines on how to <link><linkText>create a S2S VPN connection between a classic VNet and an ARM VNet</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: View the general guidelines on how to <link><linkText>create a S2S VPN connection between a classic VNet and an ARM VNet</linkText><title></title></link>.
